elements.content: A new three-dimensional Mo/O/MnII/tetrazole compound [Mn(ptz)Mo2O7] (1) (ptz = 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole) was synthesized by a hydrothermal method. It represents the first example of a molybdenum-oxide-based organic−inorganic hybrid compound templated by the ligand which connects both molybdenum and secondary metal simultaneously. The magnetic investigations reveal that the complex exhibits interesting spin-canting antiferromagnetism, and the structure studies show that compound 1 is a (4,6)-connected framework with novel (33,42,5)(34,42,62,74,82,9)(34,44,52,64,7)2 topology that has never been reported to date.
elements.clean_text: A new three-dimensional Mo/O/MnII/tetrazole compound [Mn(ptz)Mo2O7] (1) (ptz = 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole) was synthesized by a hydrothermal method. It represents the first example of a molybdenum-oxide-based organic-inorganic hybrid compound templated by the ligand which connects both molybdenum and secondary metal simultaneously. The magnetic investigations reveal that the complex exhibits interesting spin-canting antiferromagnetism, and the structure studies show that compound 1 is a (4,6)-connected framework with novel (33,42,5)(34,42,62,74,82,9)(34,44,52,64,7)2 topology that has never been reported to date.

elements.content: A new three-dimensional Mo/O/MnII/tetrazole compound [Mn(ptz)Mo2O7] (1) (ptz = 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole) was synthesized by a hydrothermal method. The magnetic investigations reveal that the complex exhibits interesting spin-canting antiferromagnetism, and the structure studies show it to be a (4,6)-connected framework with novel (33,42,5)(34,42,62,74,82,9)(34,44,52,64,7)2 topology that has never been reported to date.
elements.clean_text: A new three-dimensional Mo/O/MnII/tetrazole compound [Mn(ptz)Mo2O7] (1) (ptz = 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole) was synthesized by a hydrothermal method. The magnetic investigations reveal that the complex exhibits interesting spin-canting antiferromagnetism, and the structure studies show it to be a (4,6)-connected framework with novel (33,42,5)(34,42,62,74,82,9)(34,44,52,64,7)2 topology that has never been reported to date.

elements.content: In recent years, more and more attention has been paid to the rational design of new metal oxide based organic−inorganic hybrid materials because of the versatility of structure and exhibition of useful electronic, magnetic, optical, and mechanical properties for functional materials construction. One effective approach for the design of novel hybrid oxide materials exploits the organic molecules to modify inorganic microstructures. Zubieta and co-workers successfully apply this strategy to study the structural chemistries of the molybdenum oxide/ligand/metal. For convenience of classification, this system can be divided into three subclasses based on the role of the ligand: namely, the organic subunit incorporated as organoammonium cation; the ligand coordinated to the Mo oxide skeleton; and the ligand coordinated to heterometals. The development of new ligand systems is very important for the complexity of the structure of the Mo/O/M′/ligand family. Tetrazole, with four nitrogen electron-donating atoms, allows it to serve as either a multidentate or a bridging building block in supramolecular assemblies with interesting properties. On the other hand, the bulk magnetic properties of hybrid organic−inorganic materials are of special interest. A general strategy to prepare molecule-based magnetic materials is connecting paramagnetic transition metal ions with appropriate bridging ligands through a bottom-up approach.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, more and more attention has been paid to the rational design of new metal oxide based organic-inorganic hybrid materials because of the versatility of structure and exhibition of useful electronic, magnetic, optical, and mechanical properties for functional materials construction. One effective approach for the design of novel hybrid oxide materials exploits the organic molecules to modify inorganic microstructures. Zubieta and co-workers successfully apply this strategy to study the structural chemistries of the molybdenum oxide/ligand/metal. For convenience of classification, this system can be divided into three subclasses based on the role of the ligand: namely, the organic subunit incorporated as organoammonium cation; the ligand coordinated to the Mo oxide skeleton; and the ligand coordinated to heterometals. The development of new ligand systems is very important for the complexity of the structure of the Mo/O/M'/ligand family. Tetrazole, with four nitrogen electron-donating atoms, allows it to serve as either a multidentate or a bridging building block in supramolecular assemblies with interesting properties. On the other hand, the bulk magnetic properties of hybrid organic-inorganic materials are of special interest. A general strategy to prepare molecule-based magnetic materials is connecting paramagnetic transition metal ions with appropriate bridging ligands through a bottom-up approach.

elements.content: On this basis, we introduce the tetrazole and the secondary metal manganese into the molybdenum oxide complexes in order to obtain compounds with novel structure and interesting magnetic properties. In this paper we report a result of our attempts, a three-dimensional Mo/O/MnII/tetrazole compound [Mn (ptz) Mo2O7] (1) (ptz = 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole) by hydrothermal reaction. To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 represents the first example of a molybdenum-oxide-based organic−inorganic hybrid compound templated by the ligand which connects both molybdenum and secondary metal simultaneously. The magnetic investigations reveal that the compound exhibits interesting spin-canting antiferromagnetism, and the structure studies show that it features a (4,6)-connected framework with novel (33,42,5)(34,42,62,74,82,9)(34,44,52,64,7)2 topology that has never been reported before.
elements.clean_text: On this basis, we introduce the tetrazole and the secondary metal manganese into the molybdenum oxide complexes in order to obtain compounds with novel structure and interesting magnetic properties. In this paper we report a result of our attempts, a three-dimensional Mo/O/MnII/tetrazole compound [Mn (ptz) Mo2O7] (1) (ptz = 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole) by hydrothermal reaction. To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 represents the first example of a molybdenum-oxide-based organic-inorganic hybrid compound templated by the ligand which connects both molybdenum and secondary metal simultaneously. The magnetic investigations reveal that the compound exhibits interesting spin-canting antiferromagnetism, and the structure studies show that it features a (4,6)-connected framework with novel (33,42,5)(34,42,62,74,82,9)(34,44,52,64,7)2 topology that has never been reported before.

elements.content: The ligand 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole was prepared according to the literature. Other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out with an Elementar Vario MICTO. The Fourier transform IR spectrum was obtained on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum-one instrument using KBr pellets in the range 4000−400 cm−1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern was measured on a Rigaku DMAX2500 powder diffractometer at 40 kV and 100 mA using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA 449C thermoanalyzer under N2 (30−1200 °C range) at a heating rate of 10 K/min. The polycrystalline magnetic study was performed on a Quantum Design PPMS model 6000 magnetometer in the temperature range from 2 to 300 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

The ligand 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole was prepared according to the literature. Other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out with an Elementar Vario MICTO. The Fourier transform IR spectrum was obtained on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum-one instrument using KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern was measured on a Rigaku DMAX2500 powder diffractometer at 40 kV and 100 mA using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA 449C thermoanalyzer under N2 (30-1200 °C range) at a heating rate of 10 K/min. The polycrystalline magnetic study was performed on a Quantum Design PPMS model 6000 magnetometer in the temperature range from 2 to 300 K.

elements.content: A mixture of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O (0.070 g, 0.28 mmol), ptz (0.10 g, 0.68 mmol), (NH4)6Mo7O24 (0.150 g, 0.12 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was heated at 160 °C for 3 days in a sealed 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel under autogenously pressure after adjustment of the pH to 3.0 by the addition of concentrated HNO3 solution. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature within 1 day. Orange block crystals were isolated, washed with water, and air-dried. Yield: 0.06 g (42% based on Mn). Anal. Calcd (%) for C6H5MnMo2N5O7 (505.97): H, 0.79; C, 14.05; N, 13.6. Found (%): H, 1; C, 14.24; N, 13.84. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 582.59w, 751.3m, 1121.8w, 1384.5m, 1632.9w, 3445.7s.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of Mn(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O (0.070 g, 0.28 mmol), ptz (0.10 g, 0.68 mmol), (NH4)6Mo7O24 (0.150 g, 0.12 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was heated at 160 °C for 3 days in a sealed 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel under autogenously pressure after adjustment of the pH to 3.0 by the addition of concentrated HNO3 solution. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature within 1 day. Orange block crystals were isolated, washed with water, and air-dried. Yield: 0.06 g (42% based on Mn). Anal. Calcd (%) for C6H5MnMo2N5O7 (505.97): H, 0.79; C, 14.05; N, 13.6. Found (%): H, 1; C, 14.24; N, 13.84. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 582.59w, 751.3m, 1121.8w, 1384.5m, 1632.9w, 3445.7s.

elements.content: The single crystal of compound 1 in the present work was mounted on a glass fiber for the X-ray diffraction analysis. Data sets were collected on a Rigaku AFC7R equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) from a rotating anode generator at 293 K. Intensities were corrected for LP factors and empirical absorption using the ψ scan technique. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 with full-matrix least-squares techniques using the Siemens SHELXTL version 5 package of crystallographic software. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were fixed at their ideal positions.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The single crystal of compound 1 in the present work was mounted on a glass fiber for the X-ray diffraction analysis. Data sets were collected on a Rigaku AFC7R equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) from a rotating anode generator at 293 K. Intensities were corrected for LP factors and empirical absorption using the ψ scan technique. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 with full-matrix least-squares techniques using the Siemens SHELXTL version 5 package of crystallographic software. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were fixed at their ideal positions.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction of 1 reveals that it crystallizes in the noncentrosymmetric space group Pna21 (see Tables and ). The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one MnII cation, one Mo2O7 2− anion, and one ptz ligand. Each distorted octahedral coordination MnII center is coordinated by four μ2-bridging oxygen atoms (Mn1−O2C = 2.143(7), Mn1−O3B = 2.248(7), Mn1−O4 = 2.122(6), Mn1−O7 = 2.106(6)), and two nitrogen atoms (Mn1−N4B = 2.270(8), Mn1−N5 = 2.278(8)) from two ptz ligands (Figure). The Mo atoms are all six coordinated by five oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom (Mo1−N2 = 2.339(7), Mo2−N1 = 2.399(8)) from a ptz ligand. The Mo1 and Mo2 atoms are connected through μ2-bridging O1 to form a Mo2O7 2− anion. The inorganic Mn2+−Mo2O7 2− framework is an open three-dimensional network (Figure ). It is suggested that the ptz ligands serve as templates during the assembly so that hybrid building blocks are aggregated around them (Figure ). To the best of our knowledge, one ligand as template connected by both molybdenum and the second metal atoms simultaneously is unprecedented in the chemistry of molybdenum-oxide-based organic−inorganic hybrid complexes. Every two neighboring MnII ions along the c axis are connected by the N4 and N5 donors and the N1 and N2 are used to connect the molybdenum atoms along the a and b directions (Figure ). In this substructure, the intrachain Mn···Mn distance is 6.5882(3) and interchain ones are 6.8478(2) and 7.4865(4). This is significantly responsible for the magnetic properties, as discussed in detail later.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and General Characterization

Crystal Structure

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction of 1 reveals that it crystallizes in the noncentrosymmetric space group Pna21 (see Tables  and ). The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one MnII cation, one Mo2O7 2- anion, and one ptz ligand. Each distorted octahedral coordination MnII center is coordinated by four μ2-bridging oxygen atoms (Mn1-O2C = 2.143(7), Mn1-O3B = 2.248(7), Mn1-O4 = 2.122(6), Mn1-O7 = 2.106(6)), and two nitrogen atoms (Mn1-N4B = 2.270(8), Mn1-N5 = 2.278(8)) from two ptz ligands (Figure). The Mo atoms are all six coordinated by five oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom (Mo1-N2 = 2.339(7), Mo2-N1 = 2.399(8)) from a ptz ligand. The Mo1 and Mo2 atoms are connected through μ2-bridging O1 to form a Mo2O7 2- anion. The inorganic Mn2+-Mo2O7 2- framework is an open three-dimensional network (Figure ). It is suggested that the ptz ligands serve as templates during the assembly so that hybrid building blocks are aggregated around them (Figure ). To the best of our knowledge, one ligand as template connected by both molybdenum and the second metal atoms simultaneously is unprecedented in the chemistry of molybdenum-oxide-based organic-inorganic hybrid complexes. Every two neighboring MnII ions along the c axis are connected by the N4 and N5 donors and the N1 and N2 are used to connect the molybdenum atoms along the a and b directions (Figure ). In this substructure, the intrachain Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance is 6.5882(3) and interchain ones are 6.8478(2) and 7.4865(4). This is significantly responsible for the magnetic properties, as discussed in detail later.

elements.content: For better insight into this intricate net, a topological analysis of compound 1 was performed. Topological analysis was performed with Topos programs. We can define the ptz ligand as a four-connected node and assume that the Mo1 and Mo2 are not distinguished. This means that there are three kinds of nodes in the structure of 1, namely a 4-connected ptz ligand, 6-connected Mo atoms, and 6-connected Mn1 atoms. Thus, the overall network topology of 1 can be represented as an unprecedent (4,6)-connected framework with the Schälfli symbol of (33,42,5)(34,42,62,74,82,9)(34,44,52,64,7)2 (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: For better insight into this intricate net, a topological analysis of compound 1 was performed. Topological analysis was performed with Topos programs. We can define the ptz ligand as a four-connected node and assume that the Mo1 and Mo2 are not distinguished. This means that there are three kinds of nodes in the structure of 1, namely a 4-connected ptz ligand, 6-connected Mo atoms, and 6-connected Mn1 atoms. Thus, the overall network topology of 1 can be represented as an unprecedent (4,6)-connected framework with the Schälfli symbol of (33,42,5)(34,42,62,74,82,9)(34,44,52,64,7)2 (Figure ).

elements.content: (4, 6)-connected topology of compound 1.

elements.content: The cryomagnetic properties were measured at 1000 Oe in the temperature range 2−300 K (Figure ). The χm T value of 6.67 cm3 mol−1 K at 300 K is smaller than the spin-only one expected for two isolated Mn2+ ions (8.75 cm3 mol−1 K and S = 5/2). As the temperature is lowered, χm T first decreases gradually to a minimum of 2.5 cm3 mol−1 K at 8 K, then increases sharply to 4.04 cm3 mol−1 K at about 5.5 K, and finally drops rapidly upon further cooling. The best fit with the Curie−Weiss law gives C = 6.91 cm3 mol−1 K and θ = −10.9 K, indicating apparent intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn2+ ions. The low-temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 suggest that a mechanism of ferromagnetic-like correlations exists and develops into a weak ferromagnetic ordering. For an antiferromagnetic system, the ferromagnetic correlations can be attributed to spin canting. To fully characterize this phenomenon due to spin canting, field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) susceptibilities were measured at 50 Oe below 30 K (Figure inset). The divergence below 7 K indicates the irreversible transition of the weak ferromagnetism. To further characterize the weak ferromagnetism, field-cooled (FC) magnetizations were measured at different fields. As depicted in Figure , the susceptibility below 7.5 K is rather field-dependent and the magnetization shows no rise anymore above 500 Oe and tends to saturate at lower temperatures, indicating that the antiferromagnetic interaction is overcome by the external field. This kind of field-dependent magnetic behavior confirms the weak ferromagnetism due to spin canting. Further evidence for the spin canting in compound 1 comes from the magnetization vs filed plot at 2 K. The magnetization increases almost linearly and achieves 0.58 Nβ at 8 T (Figure inset), far from the saturation (10 Nβ) for two spin-only MnII ions. The hysteresis loop measured at 2 K is consistent with a weak ferromagnetism (Figure ). The remnant magnetization is 0.1 Nβ, and the coercive field is ca. 48.8 Oe. This is in agreement with the behavior of weak ferromagnetism due to spin canting. Thus, a conclusion may be given that the spontaneous magnetization observed is due to spin canting, with an estimated canting angle of 0.57°, calculated using the equation ψ = tan−1(M r/M s), where M r is the remnant magnetization and M s = gS is the expected saturation magnetization if all of the moments are aligned ferromagnetically. The temperature dependence of the ac magnetic susceptibilities shows that χm′ and χm′′ signals have sharp maxima at about 6.5 K (T C), which verifies the magnetic phase transition and the absence of a frequency dependence (Figure ). We can no doubt conclude that compound 1 is a spin canted antiferromagnet with weak ferromagnetism originating from spin canting below the T c = 6.5 K.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The cryomagnetic properties were measured at 1000 Oe in the temperature range 2-300 K (Figure ). The χm T value of 6.67 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K is smaller than the spin-only one expected for two isolated Mn2+ ions (8.75 cm3 mol-1 K and S = 5/2). As the temperature is lowered, χm T first decreases gradually to a minimum of 2.5 cm3 mol-1 K at 8 K, then increases sharply to 4.04 cm3 mol-1 K at about 5.5 K, and finally drops rapidly upon further cooling. The best fit with the Curie-Weiss law gives C = 6.91 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = -10.9 K, indicating apparent intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn2+ ions. The low-temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 suggest that a mechanism of ferromagnetic-like correlations exists and develops into a weak ferromagnetic ordering. For an antiferromagnetic system, the ferromagnetic correlations can be attributed to spin canting. To fully characterize this phenomenon due to spin canting, field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) susceptibilities were measured at 50 Oe below 30 K (Figure  inset). The divergence below 7 K indicates the irreversible transition of the weak ferromagnetism. To further characterize the weak ferromagnetism, field-cooled (FC) magnetizations were measured at different fields. As depicted in Figure , the susceptibility below 7.5 K is rather field-dependent and the magnetization shows no rise anymore above 500 Oe and tends to saturate at lower temperatures, indicating that the antiferromagnetic interaction is overcome by the external field. This kind of field-dependent magnetic behavior confirms the weak ferromagnetism due to spin canting. Further evidence for the spin canting in compound 1 comes from the magnetization vs filed plot at 2 K. The magnetization increases almost linearly and achieves 0.58 Nβ at 8 T (Figure  inset), far from the saturation (10 Nβ) for two spin-only MnII ions. The hysteresis loop measured at 2 K is consistent with a weak ferromagnetism (Figure ). The remnant magnetization is 0.1 Nβ, and the coercive field is ca. 48.8 Oe. This is in agreement with the behavior of weak ferromagnetism due to spin canting. Thus, a conclusion may be given that the spontaneous magnetization observed is due to spin canting, with an estimated canting angle of 0.57°, calculated using the equation ψ = tan-1(M r/M s), where M r is the remnant magnetization and M s = gS is the expected saturation magnetization if all of the moments are aligned ferromagnetically. The temperature dependence of the ac magnetic susceptibilities shows that χm' and χm'' signals have sharp maxima at about 6.5 K (T C), which verifies the magnetic phase transition and the absence of a frequency dependence (Figure ). We can no doubt conclude that compound 1 is a spin canted antiferromagnet with weak ferromagnetism originating from spin canting below the T c = 6.5 K.

elements.content: It is well-known that the occurrence of spin canting may arise from two mechanisms: (i) single-ion magnetic anisotropy or (ii) the so-called antisymmetric Dzyaloshinsky−Moriya (DM) exchange coupling. Because of the common isotropic character of the Mn2+ ion, the second factor should be responsible for the canting in 1 reported here. The 3D framework of 1 consists of linear chains of MnII, in which each pair is bridged by a μ-1, 2-ptz ligand. The chains are arrange parallel in the 3D framework and linked by a Mo2O7 anion. The main acentric-symmetry exchange pathways bridged by a ptz ligand may account for the antisymmetric interactions, whereas there are no inversion centers between the adjacent metal centers linked by a pair of μ-1,2-N−N bridges. Of course, the interchain also has a weaker contribution. The spin canting phenomenon of manganese complexes has been well studied, but compound 1 represents the first example of a manganese polymer that displays the spin canting antiferromagnetic behavior in metal oxide based organic−inorganic hybrid materials.
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that the occurrence of spin canting may arise from two mechanisms: (i) single-ion magnetic anisotropy or (ii) the so-called antisymmetric Dzyaloshinsky-Moriya (DM) exchange coupling. Because of the common isotropic character of the Mn2+ ion, the second factor should be responsible for the canting in 1 reported here. The 3D framework of 1 consists of linear chains of MnII, in which each pair is bridged by a μ-1, 2-ptz ligand. The chains are arrange parallel in the 3D framework and linked by a Mo2O7 anion. The main acentric-symmetry exchange pathways bridged by a ptz ligand may account for the antisymmetric interactions, whereas there are no inversion centers between the adjacent metal centers linked by a pair of μ-1,2-N-N bridges. Of course, the interchain also has a weaker contribution. The spin canting phenomenon of manganese complexes has been well studied, but compound 1 represents the first example of a manganese polymer that displays the spin canting antiferromagnetic behavior in metal oxide based organic-inorganic hybrid materials.

elements.content: In summary, a new three-dimensional Mo/O/MnII/tetrozole compound 1 was prepared by a hydrothermal method. This compound represents the first example of a molybdenum-oxide-based organic−inorganic hybrid complex templated by a ligand which connects both molybdenum and secondary metal. The magnetic investigations reveal that the complex exhibits interesting spin-canting antiferromagnetism, and the structure studies show that it features a (4,6)-connected framework with a novel (33;42;5)(34;42;62;74;82;9)(34;44;52;64;7)2 topology that has never been reported before. This work may have contributed much to the research on the molybdenum-oxide-based organic−inorganic hybrid complex with novel topologies and interesting magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a new three-dimensional Mo/O/MnII/tetrozole compound 1 was prepared by a hydrothermal method. This compound represents the first example of a molybdenum-oxide-based organic-inorganic hybrid complex templated by a ligand which connects both molybdenum and secondary metal. The magnetic investigations reveal that the complex exhibits interesting spin-canting antiferromagnetism, and the structure studies show that it features a (4,6)-connected framework with a novel (33;42;5)(34;42;62;74;82;9)(34;44;52;64;7)2 topology that has never been reported before. This work may have contributed much to the research on the molybdenum-oxide-based organic-inorganic hybrid complex with novel topologies and interesting magnetic properties.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O (0.070 g, 0.28 mmol), ptz (0.10 g, 0.68 mmol), (NH4)6Mo7O24 (0.150 g, 0.12 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was heated at 160 °C for 3 days in a sealed 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel under autogenously pressure after adjustment of the pH to 3.0 by the addition of concentrated HNO3 solution. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature within 1 day. Orange block crystals were isolated, washed with water, and air-dried. Yield: 0.06 g (42% based on Mn). Anal. Calcd (%) for C6H5MnMo2N5O7 (505.97): H, 0.79; C, 14.05; N, 13.6. Found (%): H, 1; C, 14.24; N, 13.84. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 582.59w, 751.3m, 1121.8w, 1384.5m, 1632.9w, 3445.7s.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of Mn(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O (0.070 g, 0.28 mmol), ptz (0.10 g, 0.68 mmol), (NH4)6Mo7O24 (0.150 g, 0.12 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was heated at 160 °C for 3 days in a sealed 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel under autogenously pressure after adjustment of the pH to 3.0 by the addition of concentrated HNO3 solution. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature within 1 day. Orange block crystals were isolated, washed with water, and air-dried. Yield: 0.06 g (42% based on Mn). Anal. Calcd (%) for C6H5MnMo2N5O7 (505.97): H, 0.79; C, 14.05; N, 13.6. Found (%): H, 1; C, 14.24; N, 13.84. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 582.59w, 751.3m, 1121.8w, 1384.5m, 1632.9w, 3445.7s.

cln_elements.content: The cryomagnetic properties were measured at 1000 Oe in the temperature range 2−300 K (Figure ). The χm T value of 6.67 cm3 mol−1 K at 300 K is smaller than the spin-only one expected for two isolated Mn2+ ions (8.75 cm3 mol−1 K and S = 5/2). As the temperature is lowered, χm T first decreases gradually to a minimum of 2.5 cm3 mol−1 K at 8 K, then increases sharply to 4.04 cm3 mol−1 K at about 5.5 K, and finally drops rapidly upon further cooling. The best fit with the Curie−Weiss law gives C = 6.91 cm3 mol−1 K and θ = −10.9 K, indicating apparent intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn2+ ions. The low-temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 suggest that a mechanism of ferromagnetic-like correlations exists and develops into a weak ferromagnetic ordering. For an antiferromagnetic system, the ferromagnetic correlations can be attributed to spin canting. To fully characterize this phenomenon due to spin canting, field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) susceptibilities were measured at 50 Oe below 30 K (Figure inset). The divergence below 7 K indicates the irreversible transition of the weak ferromagnetism. To further characterize the weak ferromagnetism, field-cooled (FC) magnetizations were measured at different fields. As depicted in Figure , the susceptibility below 7.5 K is rather field-dependent and the magnetization shows no rise anymore above 500 Oe and tends to saturate at lower temperatures, indicating that the antiferromagnetic interaction is overcome by the external field. This kind of field-dependent magnetic behavior confirms the weak ferromagnetism due to spin canting. Further evidence for the spin canting in compound 1 comes from the magnetization vs filed plot at 2 K. The magnetization increases almost linearly and achieves 0.58 Nβ at 8 T (Figure inset), far from the saturation (10 Nβ) for two spin-only MnII ions. The hysteresis loop measured at 2 K is consistent with a weak ferromagnetism (Figure ). The remnant magnetization is 0.1 Nβ, and the coercive field is ca. 48.8 Oe. This is in agreement with the behavior of weak ferromagnetism due to spin canting. Thus, a conclusion may be given that the spontaneous magnetization observed is due to spin canting, with an estimated canting angle of 0.57°, calculated using the equation ψ = tan−1(M r/M s), where M r is the remnant magnetization and M s = gS is the expected saturation magnetization if all of the moments are aligned ferromagnetically. The temperature dependence of the ac magnetic susceptibilities shows that χm′ and χm′′ signals have sharp maxima at about 6.5 K (T C), which verifies the magnetic phase transition and the absence of a frequency dependence (Figure ). We can no doubt conclude that compound 1 is a spin canted antiferromagnet with weak ferromagnetism originating from spin canting below the T c = 6.5 K.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The cryomagnetic properties were measured at 1000 Oe in the temperature range 2-300 K (Figure ). The χm T value of 6.67 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K is smaller than the spin-only one expected for two isolated Mn2+ ions (8.75 cm3 mol-1 K and S = 5/2). As the temperature is lowered, χm T first decreases gradually to a minimum of 2.5 cm3 mol-1 K at 8 K, then increases sharply to 4.04 cm3 mol-1 K at about 5.5 K, and finally drops rapidly upon further cooling. The best fit with the Curie-Weiss law gives C = 6.91 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = -10.9 K, indicating apparent intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn2+ ions. The low-temperature magnetic behaviors of 1 suggest that a mechanism of ferromagnetic-like correlations exists and develops into a weak ferromagnetic ordering. For an antiferromagnetic system, the ferromagnetic correlations can be attributed to spin canting. To fully characterize this phenomenon due to spin canting, field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) susceptibilities were measured at 50 Oe below 30 K (Figure  inset). The divergence below 7 K indicates the irreversible transition of the weak ferromagnetism. To further characterize the weak ferromagnetism, field-cooled (FC) magnetizations were measured at different fields. As depicted in Figure , the susceptibility below 7.5 K is rather field-dependent and the magnetization shows no rise anymore above 500 Oe and tends to saturate at lower temperatures, indicating that the antiferromagnetic interaction is overcome by the external field. This kind of field-dependent magnetic behavior confirms the weak ferromagnetism due to spin canting. Further evidence for the spin canting in compound 1 comes from the magnetization vs filed plot at 2 K. The magnetization increases almost linearly and achieves 0.58 Nβ at 8 T (Figure  inset), far from the saturation (10 Nβ) for two spin-only MnII ions. The hysteresis loop measured at 2 K is consistent with a weak ferromagnetism (Figure ). The remnant magnetization is 0.1 Nβ, and the coercive field is ca. 48.8 Oe. This is in agreement with the behavior of weak ferromagnetism due to spin canting. Thus, a conclusion may be given that the spontaneous magnetization observed is due to spin canting, with an estimated canting angle of 0.57°, calculated using the equation ψ = tan-1(M r/M s), where M r is the remnant magnetization and M s = gS is the expected saturation magnetization if all of the moments are aligned ferromagnetically. The temperature dependence of the ac magnetic susceptibilities shows that χm' and χm'' signals have sharp maxima at about 6.5 K (T C), which verifies the magnetic phase transition and the absence of a frequency dependence (Figure ). We can no doubt conclude that compound 1 is a spin canted antiferromagnet with weak ferromagnetism originating from spin canting below the T c = 6.5 K.

metadata.title: A New Molybdenum-Oxide-Based Organic−Inorganic Hybrid Compound Templated by 5-(2-Pyridyl)tetrazole with New Topology and Canted Antiferromagnetism
